results.title: Une Partie de Campagne = a Day in the Country
results.brief_description:
In this bitter-sweet Maupassant vignette set in 1860, a Parisian merchant takes his family for a day in the country. The picnic and a seduction form the centre of the tale. Renoir replaces Maupassant’s detached observation with a celebration of nature. While an impressionistic sense of transcience is perfectly captured, it is Renoir’s clear perception of character aided by Kosma’s music that generates the film’s depth of feeling.

Credits: Producer, Pierre Braunberger ; director, writer, Jean Renoir ; photography, Claude Renoir, Jean Bourgoin ; assistants, Luchino Visconti, Jacques Becker, Henri Cartier-Bresson ; music, Joseph Kosma ; editor, Marguerite Renoir.
Cast: Sylvia Bataille, Georges Darnoux, Jeanne Marken, Gabriello, .

results.title: Quatre-Vingt Treize
results.brief_description:
Resorting to prints and songs, this documentary gives a newsreel-style account of the the tragic events of 1793 known as ‘La Terreur’. 1793 is characterised by the overthrowing of the constitutional monarchy and the emprisonment of the royal family at the Prison du Temple. The Paris mob (the ‘Sans-Culottes’) rules and exerts pressure on the Convention, still dominated by the bourgeois Girondins (led by Brissot) and the Montagnards (led by Robespierre). On the borders, the situation is equally precarious with the armies of the coalised nations threatening to invade the country and save the monarchs.

Credits: director, Jean Vidal ; writers, Edouard Bruley, Jean Vidal.
Cast: Rene Lebrun, Jacques Tessier [narration only].

results.title: Nubie 64
results.brief_description: This documentary produced by the ‘Institut Geographique National’ describes the UNESCO’s programme to save the temple complex of Abu Simbel under the threat of total submersion by the damming of the Nile river at Assouan.

results.title: Pablo Picasso Peintre = Pablo Picasso Painter
results.brief_description:
A biography of Pablo Picasso, abundantly illustratd with home movies and newsreels. The purpose of the filmmaker is to explain how the painter came to embody the 20th century.

Credits: Director, Frederic Rossif ; writer, Helene Parmelin ‘ photography, Daniel barrau ; music, Vangelis Papathanassiou.
Cast: Suzanne Flon, Pierre Vaneck [narration only].

results.title: Conquerant de L'inutile = Borders of the Impossible
results.brief_description:
This documentary tells the life story of Lionel Terray who became one of the most famous French mountaineer after World War II. The footage used in this documentary has been filmed by friends and fellow mountaineers like Maurice Herzog and Jacques Ertaud. It contains breathtaking scenes of expeditions conducted by Terray in the Himalayas and the Andes.

Credits: Director, Marcel Ichac ; music, Francois de Roubaix.

results.title: Rendez-Vous de L'ete = Summer Rendez-Vous
results.brief_description:
This documentary profiles the various disciplines making up Track and Field Athletics as well as coaching techniques.

Credits: Director, Jacques Ertaud ; editor, Emma le Chanois.

results.title: Nuit et Brouillard = Night and Fog
results.brief_description:
“‘Nuit et Brouillard’ establishes the classic photographic dichotomy of the Holocaust film, according to which the past is seen in black and white and the present in colour. The aesthetic quality of the film stems from the inter-relation of Cayrol’s text and Eisler’s music with Resnais’s editing, which juxtaposes colour images of the ruins of the death camps with black and white archive footage of the camps and their victims during the war. Resnais thus excavates the horrors lying beneath the deceptively banal landscapes of the present day, landscapes which like those of Lanzman’s ‘Shoah’ are at times startingly beautiful with blue or pink skies and orange trees. It has even been remarked that these colours were too bright, like open wound or ‘draining blood’. The disembodied and anonymous narration in ‘Nuit et Brouillard’, the film’s universal concerns, and the absence of any reference to the extermination of the Jews might be taken as conforming to the myth of ‘resistancialisme’. Although a specifically French context is given by brief allusions to the camps at Pithiviers and Compiegne, and to the deportation of Jews from the Velodrome d’Hiver in Paris, the image which most explicitly challenge the Gaullist myth - a French policeman surveying the camps at Pithiviers - was censored.” Reference: Guy Austin. ‘Contemporary French Cinema’. Manchester University Press, 1996.

Credits: Producer, Anatole Dauman ; director, Alain Resnais ; photography, Sacha Vierny, Ghislain Cloquet ; music, Hans Eisler ; editor, Henri Colpi.

results.title: New Wave: French Connection
results.brief_description:
A documentary account of a Punk/New Wave festival held in the Fourvieres roman theatre of Lyons in the summer of 1978. Fourvieres made its mark in the history of entertainement as a place where Christians were thrown to the lions. In 1978 only great expectations are shattered as ‘Marie et les garcons’ are booed off the stage. The concert showcases French exponents of the New Wave movement, such as Telephone, Bijou, Starshooters as well as Heavy Metal band Ganafoul and reggae outfit Cimarons, all working hard to prove that there is a world of peaceful harmony outside Disco. The documentary ends with that also familiar concert ritual: an ocean of empty beer cans being swept away.
Cast: Interviews by Jean-Francois Bizot.
